newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Jakarta stocks end firmer on bargain hunting.
newsitem.headline: Jakarta stocks end firmer on bargain hunting.

text.p: Bargain-hunting in blue chip counters led by Telkom raised Jakarta's stock index by the close on Monday but overall volume was light, brokers said.
The composite index rose 4.67 points, or 0.71 percent, to 663.20 points after touching a low of 658.05 points in early trade. Advancers led decliners 61 to 43, with 75 counters unchanged.
Total turn-over was modest, estimated at about 280 billion rupiah compared to about 326 billion rupiah last Friday.
The LQ45 index -- representing the 45 very liquid counters on the Jakarta bourse -- closed 0.84 percent, or 1.14 points, higher at 136.38 points.
A broker with a Malaysian firm said he expected trading to remain slow on Tuesday but added the index may moving upward as more bargain hunters were likely to enter the market.

Brokers ascribed the slow trading on Monday to a holiday on Wall Street and also news of the riot in Banjarmasin, a city in South Kalimantan province in Borneo island, but said the impact was minor as it was far away from Jakarta.

"Trading will remain slow up to the end of this month, until the (May 29) election is over, I guess. The market will be normal again next June because of some initial public offerings will take place," the broker said. "At the same time, many companies will announce their first quarter results," he added.
Cement maker Semen Gresik and Bank Negara Indonesia were among the targets of bargain hunters, brokers said.

Small property firm Mas Murni Indonesia was the most active stock, rising 50 rupiah to 925 on 13.7 million shares on what brokers said was due to revived speculation of a possible take-over and rights issue.
